text:
Ok so I'm in love with what Databox is doing on their blog and I've been trying to introduce more roundtable content/content-based networking in our strategy

BUT

*Do y'all have any proven workflows for landing quotes for roundtable articles?* On our end these projects always seem to get stuck on this stage, I wonder if I'm doing something wrong. Are my emails too complicated? Should I be using a Google Form/Typeform for this or something? Are y'all using forms?

Any and all advice will be greatly appreciated, thanks :pray:

text: Databox is using HARO all the time to source quotes. If your website has a bit of authority you should try and post quotes requests with HARO :slightly_smiling_face: Not sure how many answers you’re going to get but since you seem to like what Databox is doing and that I see them a lot in my HARO requests, I think you might find what you need there :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Spela hustles hard for HARO responses and promotion once people have responded.

I've never known such a simple tactic have such good results.

That said, with some round up posts like this, it does become a chore to read.

Dave said
Michaela opined
Reese quoted
Roksana thinks

Rather than a lesson in synonyms for "said," I'd love to see someone be more creative when presenting round up posts.

text: In our company, we tap our Customer Success and Sales teams to provide warm intros for any roundtable-type projects. These guys already have the contact info of great companies and can make introductions for me. They’re much more responsive than cold reach-outs and are generally of better quality than those I get from HARO.

elements.text: In our company, we tap our Customer Success and Sales teams to provide warm intros for any roundtable-type projects. These guys already have the contact info of great companies and can make introductions for me. They’re much more responsive than cold reach-outs and are generally of better quality than those I get from HARO.

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?
Another benefit is that it offers our Sales people a touchpoint that they can use to stay top of mind with their customer, and the customer feels flattered that we would include them.

elements.text: Another benefit is that it offers our Sales people a touchpoint that they can use to stay top of mind with their customer, and the customer feels flattered that we would include them.

text: So good your internal folks do that. In some (and I think I'm in good company if I say most) marketers struggle to get internal buy-in for most things that aren't directly related to other department's goals.

text:
Howdy everyone!

I need to pick you brain about creating better types of Bofu and Mofu content. 

For context: We’re providing multi-channel help desk, AI-powered chatbot, and live chat solutions to e-commerce store owners. Our company is still new in the content marketing game. Many of you suggested to work our way up from the bottom when it comes about content marketing. 

Can you suggest which types of Mofu and Bofu content would work better for an early-stage SaaS company?

I asked Jimmy about this and thought why not ask fellow content marketing experts about this.

text:
1. Start by creating a list of problems that your product solves. 
2. Use a tool like Ahrefs or Semrush to look through the search data and try and find what keywords people are using when they're searching for answers to those problems. 
3. Create content that answers those searcher's problems/questions, and show how your product is the best way to solve their problem

elements.text: Start by creating a list of problems that your product solves.
Use a tool like Ahrefs or Semrush to look through the search data and try and find what keywords people are using when they're searching for answers to those problems.
Create content that answers those searcher's problems/questions, and show how your product is the best way to solve their problem

text: My team launched an expert contributor program earlier this year -- I will say, it helped us to set clear guardrails from the start about what we wanted this program to help us achieve. We're focused on brand awareness / getting our name in front of a wider audience, so we aim to partner with contributors who are somewhat established experts and have large followings of their own. For now, we've also made this a "closed" program where not just anyone can sign up or apply.

text:
Hey all, I have a question about pricing. :heavy_dollar_sign:

I'm working on a proposal for a prospect who wants a strategy their small team can execute internally for the next year.

Here's what they'd like included:
- what channels to focus on
- frequency for posting
- the type of content 
- recommendations for campaigns
- content calendar
- recommendations for driving engagement
- any other best practices that startups should be mindful of

I know all of this needs to be informed by basic strategy services I provide (setting goals, creating/updating customer personas and journeys, doing customer research to discover the communities where they hang out, coming up with content buckets, etc.), so that's where I'd start.

What would you recommend charging (ballpark figure) for all of this together? It seems like value pricing would be the way to go, but I also want to be mindful that they're on a startup budget.

TIA!

I know all of this needs to be informed by basic strategy services I provide (setting goals, creating/updating customer personas and journeys, doing customer research to discover the communities where they hang out, coming up with content buckets, etc.), so that's where I'd start.

What would you recommend charging (ballpark figure) for all of this together? It seems like value pricing would be the way to go, but I also want to be mindful that they're on a startup budget.

TIA!

text:
The quick answer is how much time you think you need to invest into creating the deliverables times the value of your time. I usually use a multiplier on top of that based up on how badly I want the project. If my workload is already high and its not a super compelling project, that multiple is higher than if it’s a project I REALLY want to win or my workload is lighter than usual. For something like this I’d be pitching a $3-5k range.

But as a counterpoint, I was just listening to <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fWW_TX2naFA&t=20m40s|Tom Critchlow talk about this on podcast> today - instead of selling a content strategy, sell your ability to embed yourself in their business, learn what they’re doing right/wrong, and improve their content program. Think the analogy of going to the doctor asking for a specific operation vs letting the doctor examine, run tests and determine the course of action.

In addition to the custom built strategy that you create for them over the course of this, you also sell in “strategy stewardship” which has you working within their content team to oversee execution of the strategy, see firsthand how that strategy is working, and provide timely fact-based and observational recommendations to iterate and improve over time.

Not only is the outcome increased time to value, but you have the ability to stretch a 1 time project that may or may not help them, into an ongoing engagement that increases the likelihood of that content program driving ROI and increases your own monthly recurring revenue.

Food for thought :)

attachments.title: Strategy Sessions Marketing Podcast | Tom Critchlow Season 2 Episode 6
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/fWW_TX2naFA?feature=oembed&start=1240&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

text:
Gary's above answer is excellent.

The _only_ thing I would add is that this is a proposal for an entire annual strategy - not just a quarter/smaller increment. I'd likely price higher because of that (again, depending on how badly you want this job/your current workload).

text:
<@U02GYR8TM96> Yeah, I'm not sure the prospect entirely understands the scope of what's involved in planning an annual strategy, especially since they don't have much of any previous content/strategic data to draw from.

I may recommend they go 6 months and re-evaluate to maximize the strategy's effectiveness.

text: <@U01LCCTLT8T> Thanks for your reply! Do you try to double dip with SEO at all or is it purely a social play?

elements.text: Thanks for your reply! Do you try to double dip with SEO at all or is it purely a social play?

text: So far we haven't tried to double dip with SEO, mainly a social / thought leadership play. We have seen some of these pieces get picked up by industry trade newsletters (w/o any intervention from us) which is an added lift.
